Aw, Youâ€™re welcome. 
Forgive my little soap box though.  I see youâ€™ve run into the self defense mechanism of mental illness. Thatâ€™s how it defends itself by making us think we donâ€™t deserve it, that others are in worse shape. The illnesses lie to us because like any illness they donâ€™t want to just go away. They make us compare ourselves to the worst examples so that weâ€™ll go â€œwell I guess Iâ€™m not THAT bad, I should suck it up.â€ 

From everything I read -and I think you said it quite well- you do indeed deserve and need help. Especially once you feel like you canâ€™t handle it anymore. My mistake was I tried to power-girl my way through it. All the signs were there but because I wasnâ€™t screaming at telephone poles or cutting myself it meant that I didnâ€™t deserve help. I was constantly comparing myself with those worse off. The best thing I was told after I ended up in hospital was that this â€œwasnâ€™t some race to the bottomâ€. I didnâ€™t need to reach some arbitrary number of standard before I became deserving of help. 

Itâ€™s not always easy to get help I understand, but youâ€™re mind is worth fighting that battle over. You donâ€™t deserve to have to feel that way and you donâ€™t deserve to fight a scrappy battle with an uncaring illness with one arm tied behind your back. 

Iâ€™m sorry, I hope I donâ€™t come off as too preachy. I just know what itâ€™s like and Iâ€™m over sensitive since it literally almost killed me.

Grimmy here, I got it at 44. It can indeed happen.

Apart from hallucinations as a little girl my life was pretty normal up until three years ago when my hallucinations came back at 41. Even then enough other stuff seemed normal that I tried ignoring them and basically tried to change my diet and exercise and outdoor my way out of it. I got my waistline back but other than that it didnâ€™t work out so well for me. My hallucinations increased and towards the middle of last year I started getting paranoid that something was always wrong with me- often some sort of brain parasite or something like that. Shortly after that I finally crawled into my first psychiatrist visit and immediately began to be treated for schizophrenia.

Oh. My. Word. Yesssss. Iâ€™d almost rather go to the dentist than make a phone call. I get sweaty, my breath gets short, sometimes I panic, Iâ€™ve even had to lock myself in a closet and freaking cry because I was so scared - and embarrassed as hell for being scared.

Yessss, thank you! I feel like unless I was hiding under a desk with a foil hat, or yelling at a telephone pole that some people wouldnâ€™t believe me. Whatâ€™s worse is it can make people like you and me feel guilty for even trying to get help because thereâ€™s someone â€œworse offâ€ or some shit like that. But this isnâ€™t a race to the bottom. I donâ€™t need to reach some low before I need or even deserve help.

I mean you could be quirky, but if those â€œquirksâ€ are causing you negative experiences then you deserve to feel better. I donâ€™t like gate keeping, and Iâ€™m not a doctor, but you might just check in with a doctor concerning those hallucinations. Some people might say â€œthose are normal hypnogogic hallucinationsâ€ I say let a doctor tell you that instead of internet experts. I understand your possible confusion with wondering how you could possibly be schizophrenic (Iâ€™ll just say it) and yet be ok at being social; but again that may just need a doctor to examine and go through. Despite my schizophrenia Iâ€™m still able to chat it up (albeit with a lot more effort since I became ill) and appear socially able. 

Mental illness can be just that varied. And you may be absolutely fine. Just quirky. But you deserve the peace of mind that can come with knowing. And if you do have an illness, having attention called to it early on can give you a better shot at recovery. 

Best of luck!

Not too personal at all.
